title: 1975 PGA Championship
text:
The 1975 PGA Championship was the 57th <a href="PGA%20Championship">PGA Championship</a>, played August 7–10 at the South Course of <a href="Firestone%20Country%20Club">Firestone Country Club</a> in <a href="Akron%2C%20Ohio">Akron, Ohio</a>. <a href="Jack%20Nicklaus">Jack Nicklaus</a>, an Ohio native, won the fourth of his five PGA Championships and the fourteenth of his eighteen <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major</a> titles, two strokes ahead of runner-up <a href="Bruce%20Crampton">Bruce Crampton</a>. He was also the 54-hole leader, four strokes ahead of Crampton.
It was the second major of the year for Nicklaus, who won his fifth <a href="Augusta%20National%20Golf%20Club%23Green%20jacket">green jacket</a> in April at the <a href="1975%20Masters%20Tournament">Masters</a>, and the fourth of five times that he won two majors in the same calendar year. 
Through <a href="2021%20PGA%20Championship">2021</a>, this was the fourth and most recent time a player won the Masters and PGA Championship in the same calendar year. Nicklaus had previously won both in <a href="1963%20PGA%20Championship">1963</a>, preceded by <a href="Jack%20Burke%20Jr.">Jack Burke Jr.</a> (<a href="1956%20PGA%20Championship">1956</a>) and <a href="Sam%20Snead">Sam Snead</a> (<a href="1949%20PGA%20Championship">1949</a>). Nicklaus also held both titles after a Masters win in <a href="1972%20Masters%20Tournament">1972</a>, and <a href="Tiger%20Woods">Tiger Woods</a> held all four major titles after his Masters win in <a href="2001%20Masters%20Tournament">2001</a>.
This was the third PGA Championship at the South Course, which previously hosted in <a href="1960%20PGA%20Championship">1960</a> and <a href="1966%20PGA%20Championship">1966</a>. It also a former venue for the <a href="WGC-Bridgestone%20Invitational">WGC-Bridgestone Invitational</a>, which began in <a href="1976%20PGA%20Tour">1976</a> as the "World Series of Golf" on the <a href="PGA%20Tour">PGA Tour</a>, preceded by the <a href="American%20Golf%20Classic">American Golf Classic</a>, which debuted in <a href="1961%20PGA%20Tour">1961</a>.
Past champions in the field.
Missed the cut.
